awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Automatic, Digital Classification and Counting of Mosquitos to Allow More Effective Vector Control
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the creation of an end-to-end platform for digital mosquito surveillance that can support the vital work of vector control districts. Effective vector control is essential to reducing the spread of diseases including West Nile, Eastern Equine Encephalitis and Zika. Currently, mosquito surveillance is typically done using mechanical traps, which require significant labor to survive. The project will significantly improve the quality and ease of insect surveillance, thus allowing more effective mosquito control. This effort will improve mosquito suppression efforts, while reducing labor costs and the volume of pesticides that must be used. Reducing the volume of pesticides has further positive benefits to society at large: it will reduce pollution and colony collapse disorder in beneficial bees. Beyond area-wide surveillance, the hardware/ algorithms/ representations/ data-models created in this project will be useful to scientists that study mosquito-vectored diseases. For example, the solutions can be used to measure the effectiveness of a new attractant or repellent.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will investigate techniques to improve state-of-the-art mosquito classification and counting, with the goal of producing a platform that allows inexpensive, real-time, insect surveillance to support mosquito suppression efforts. Although digital sensors have the potential to remove the burden of manually counting the insects, currently the vector control technicians must still visit the traps frequently to change the carbon dioxide (CO2) gas cylinders (the lure) and the batteries. The reason why both CO2 and batteries deplete so rapidly is because they are left on all day. Because the team is sensing insects in real time, they have the unique ability to actuate the gas cylinders and fan/light to sample the distribution of insect arrivals. The team can also optimize the trade-off between conserving resources and the precision of measurement of mosquito density.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project was the creation of an end-to-end platform for digital mosquito surveillance that can support the critical work of vector control districts. Effective vector control is essential to reducing the spread of insect-spread diseases such as West Nile, Eastern Equine Encephalitis and Zika. Currently, mosquito surveillance is done using mechanical traps, which require significant labor to maintain and service. This project has significantly improved the quality and ease of insect surveillance, thus allowing more effective mosquito control. Ongoing field trials suggest that this will improve mosquito suppression efforts, reducing labor costs and the volume of pesticides that must be used. Note that reducing the volume of pesticides has further positive benefits to society at large: as it will reduce pollution and colony collapse disorder in beneficial insects like bees. Beyond area-wide surveillance, the hardware/ algorithms/ representations/ data-models created in this project have been shared with academic scientists that study mosquito-vectored diseases, to aid in their research efforts. An additional broader impact was the creation and offering of a machine learning course aimed at K12 students, that use students’ natural interest and familiarity with insects to make complex machine learning algorithms more visual, intuitive and accessible.
The intellectual merit of this SBIR Phase I project includes: I) Optimizing the optical attraction of mosquitoes to traps, thereby reducing the need for expensive CO2 lures. II) Optimizing the CO2 gas release rate by producing short bursts of CO2 that mimic large mammal’s breath, again reducing the need for expensive CO2 lures. III) Optimizing the machine learning models that are used to automatically classify the insects that arrive at the traps.
The commercial potential of this SBIR Phase I project is in improving state-of-the-art mosquito classification and counting, producing a platform that allows inexpensive, real-time, insect surveillance to support mosquito suppression efforts. Although existing digital sensors already had the potential to remove the burden of manually counting the insects, currently the vector control technicians must still visit the traps frequently to change the carbon dioxide (CO2) gas cylinders (the lure) and the batteries. The reason why both CO2 and batteries deplete so rapidly is because they are left on all day. This project showed that by automatically sensing the insects, it is possible to automatically actuate the gas cylinders and fan/light to significantly extend the required service interval.


Last Modified: 08/12/2024
Modified by: Shailendra Singh
